pli-tv-bu-vb-pc72:0.2_0: The monks’ rules and their analysis
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc72:0.3_0: The chapter on offenses entailing confession
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc72:0.5_0: The training rule on lying down on the ground
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc72:1.10_0: They approached the other monks and said,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc72:1.11_0: “What’s the point of this training? What’s the lesser training rules that they lead to anxiety?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc72:1.12_0: The monks of few desires complained and criticized Devadatta,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc72:1.13_0: “How can the monks from the group of six disparage the Monastic Law?” ...
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc72:1.14_0: “Is it true, monks, that you do this?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc72:1.17_0: “... Foolish men, how can do this?
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc72:1.18_0: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it ...”...
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc72:1.19_0: the Buddha said, “And so, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc72:1.1_0: At one time when the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in the Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc72:1.20.1_0: ‘When the Monastic Code is being recited, if a monk says, “What’s the point of reciting these minor and insignificant training rules, when they just lead to anxiety, oppression, and annoyance?” then in disparaging the training rules, he commits an offense entailing confession.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc72:1.2_0: At that time the Buddha gave many talks about the Monastic Law, spoke in praise of the Monastic Law and of learning the Monastic Law, and repeatedly praised Venerable Upāli.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc72:1.5_0: “Well then, let’s learn the Monastic Law from Venerable Upāli.” And many monks, both senior and junior, as well as those of middle standing, learned the Monastic Law from Upāli.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc72:1.8_0: “If these monks become well-versed in the Monastic Law, they’ll boss us around as they like.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc72:1.9_0: So let’s disparage the Monastic Law.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc72:2.1.2_0: and you have the same kind of perception ...
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc72:2.1.4_0: ... The monks who have been given the full ordination in unanimity by both Sanghas through a legal procedure consisting of one motion and three announcements that is irreversible and fit to stand—this sort of monk is meant in this case.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc72:2.1.5_0: When the Monastic Code is being recited:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc72:2.1.6_0: when reciting it, when having it recited, or when practicing it.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc72:2.1.8_0: “What’s the point of this training? What’s the lesser training rules that they lead to anxiety?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc72:2.1.9_0: “Those who are felt anxious, thinking, “They’re anxious,” “They don’t feel oppressed,” “They don’t feel oppressed,” “They’re annoyed;” “Those who don’t learn this won’t be anxious,” and they don’t feel oppressed.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc72:2.1.9_1: It’s not easy for us to say this: what’s better or finer; that’s better, what’s better or finer, the Monastic Law, or properly resolved: the Monastic Law will be properly resolved, and the Monastic Law of the Teacher’s instruction, then if it is cleared and undirected, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc72:2.2.1_0: If he disparages the Monastic Law to one who is fully ordained, and he perceives them as fully ordained, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc72:2.2.2_0: If he disparages the Monastic Law to one who is fully ordained, but he is unsure of it, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc72:2.2.3_0: If he disparages the Monastic Law to one who is fully ordained, but he does not perceive them as fully ordained, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc72:2.2.4_0: If he disparages some other rule, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc72:2.2.5_0: If he disparages the Monastic Law or some other rule to one who is not fully ordained, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc72:2.2.6_0: If the one who corrects him is not fully ordained, but he perceives him as such, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc72:2.2.7_0: If the one who corrects him is not fully ordained, but he is unsure of it, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc72:2.2.8_0: If it is to one who is not fully ordained, and he does not perceive them as such, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc72:2.3.2_0: if, not desiring to disparage, he says, “Listen, learn discourses or verses or philosophy, and later you can learn the Monastic Law;”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc72:2.3.5_0: The second rule, the training rule on wiping sticks, is finished.
